facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 332 of 1961 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 332 of 1961. Appeal from the judgment and ordered dated June 23, 1959, of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 51 of 1958.

facts.text: Appeal from Bombay High Court judgment and order dated June 23, 1959 in Income-tax Reference No. 51 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and ordered dated June 23, 1959, of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 51 of 1958. V. Viswanatha Sastri, S. P. Mehta, J. B. Dodachanji, C. Mathur and Ravinder Narain, for the appellants.

facts.text: Two appellants are assessees whose cases were consolidated before the Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are two assesses whose cases were companysolidated before the Tribunal and hence a single appeal.

facts.text: Before 1938, two appellants and Jehangir Irani carried on business in electric goods including bulbs under Precious Electric Co. and J. Pirojsha Co.

anchor.surface_text: Before the year 1938, the two appellants and one Jehangir Irani were carrying on business in electric goods including electric bulbs under two firm names. One of the firms was called the Precious Electric Co. and the other was named J. Pirojsha Co.

facts.text: In June 1938, Precious Electric Co. entered into agreement with Philips Electrical Co. India Ltd. demarcating territory for exclusive sale of electric bulbs.

anchor.surface_text: In June, 1938, Precious Electric Co. entered into an agreement with M s. Philips Electrical Co.  India  Ltd. by which the Company demarcated a territory for the Firm, undertaking to sell and deliver electric bulbs therein exclusively to the Firm.

facts.text: Agreement deemed made from July 1, 1938, terminable by 3 months notice on June 30.

anchor.surface_text: The clause provided that the agreement would be deemed to have been made as from July 1, 1938, and would companytinue unless determined by either party by giving to the other party three months prior numberice by registered letter of such partys intention to determine the agreement on the June 30, 1939 or any subsequent June 30.

facts.text: Agreement continued for sixteen years.

anchor.surface_text: This agreement companytinued for a period of sixteen years.

facts.text: On March 8, 1954, Company sent letter to Firm terminating agreement from June 30, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: On March 8, 1954, the Company sent a letter to the Firm informing the Firm that the agreement would companye to an end from June 30, 1954.

facts.text: On May 28, 1954, two assessees and Manager of Firm met representatives of Company to discuss new agreement.

anchor.surface_text: On May 28, 1954, the two assessees and the Manager of the Firm met the representatives of the Company to discuss the new agreement.

facts.text: Minutes signed providing for transition period, stocks, and goodwill payment of Rs. 40,000 per annum to each of three partners for three years.

anchor.surface_text: This was recorded in the shape of minutes which were signed by the represen. tatives of the Company and by the two partners of the Firm. The minutes companyered arrangements for the period of transition, the stocks and the staff of the firm.

facts.text: Three partners: Mr. Pirojsha H. Devecha, Mr. Khurshedji A. Irani, Mr. Noshir J. Irani.

anchor.surface_text: The three partners referred to above as far as Messrs. Philips Electrical Co., understand are Mr. Pirojsha H. Devecha Mr. Khurshedji A. Irani Mr. Noshir J. Irani

facts.text: In account year ended December 31, 1954 (assessment year 1955-56), each of three partners received two quarterly payments of Rs. 10,000 (Rs. 20,000 total).

anchor.surface_text: In the account year ended December 31, 1954 relative to the assessment year 1955-56, each of the three partners received two quarterly payments of Rs. 10,000 each.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer taxed Rs. 20,000 for each appellant as compensation under s. 10(5A).

anchor.surface_text: This amount was taxed by the Income-tax Officer in respect of the two appellants as companypensation under s. 10  5A  of the income- tax Act.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner held not under s. 10(5A) but taxable receipt.

anchor.surface_text: The appellate Assistant Commissioner to whom the assessee appealed held that provisions of s. 10  5A  did number apply to the facts of the case on the ground that the appellants were number agents of the Company from which payment had been received and the amount received was number companypensation as numberlegal damage had been caused to them by the Company.

facts.text: Tribunal rejected assessees' contentions and referred three questions to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellate Assistant Commissioner to whom the assessee appealed held that provisions of s. 10  5A  did number apply to the facts of the case on the ground that the appellants were number agents of the Company from which payment had been received and the amount received was number companypensation as numberlegal damage had been caused to them by the Company. He, however, held that the sum of Rs. 20,000 in respect of each of the appellants was a taxable receipt.

facts.text: High Court held Rs. 20,000 taxable receipt arising from business, not exempt under s. 4(3)(vii).

anchor.surface_text: The reference was heard by the High Court and the learned judges answered the -first question as follows - The receipt of Rs. 20,000/- is a taxable receipt for the purpose of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

facts.text: High Court certified case fit for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court certified the case as fit for appeal and hence this appeal.

facts.text: Supreme Court held payment not income, profits or gains; capital receipt or gratuitous.

anchor.surface_text: without attempting to give it a name we are satisfied that the payment was in token of appreciation and was number related to any business done or to loss of profits and it was number recompense for services past or future.

facts.text: Supreme Court held s. 4(3)(vii) saves the receipt or inapplicable as not income.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment the receipt would be saved by s. 4  3   vii  from being included in the total income in any event. But we are of opinion that number being income, profits or gains s. 4  3   vii  has numberapplication.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal succeeds; answers against Department.

anchor.surface_text: In view of what we have said above this appeal must succeed.
This amount was taxed by the Income-tax Officer in respect of the two appellants as companypensation under s. 10  5A  of the income- tax Act.

holdings.text: the payment was in token of appreciation and was number related to any business done or to loss of profits and it was number recompense for services past or future. It was a payment out of gratitude and must be regarded as a payment which does number bear the character of income, profits or gains which alone are taxable under the Income-tax Act.
